context: Moreover, the signs of these terms in Eq. (7) provide significance to the obtained results. For instance, a large pH value would result in a higher degradation rate because the intermediates are acidic, a higher pH would generate an improvement. Furthermore, the influence of pH2 is negative because overly alkaline conditions inhibit the growth of the bacterium. The interaction plots between T and pH, pH and S, pH and I, and S and I are presented in Fig. 2 as A, B, C and D four patterns. In Fig. 2A, when the pH was 8 and the T was varied, a large amplitude for degradation rate was obtained (26.3% difference) compared to the effect when the pH was set to 4 (3.7% difference). Therefore, a high pH could compensate for a lower T according to the 52% difference in degradation when the T was set to 25°C and the pH was varied from 4 to 8. In Fig. 2B, when the S was set to 3%, there was a 25.7% difference in degradation, compared to the large amplitude of degradation observed when the S was set to 0 (49.3% difference). Alternatively, a high pH would not compensate for the inhibition caused by higher S because the DMS degradation was increasing from 10.3% to 40.6% when the pH was set to 4, but only increasing from 10.3% to 36% when S was set to 3%.
